Gay health to your haunts of repose,</br>Where innocence, harmless of blame,</br>Her jewels of peace, in the close,</br>Has scatter'd to brighten the fame</br>Of Paridel, conscious of truth</br>Whose heart's as remote from disdain</br>As envy's unknown to his youth,</br>Or dissimulation the plain.

Gay health, to your haunts I repair'd,</br>Fair summer had brighten'd each field,</br>The hills and the vallies declar'd</br>The pleasures which nature reveal'd;</br>'Twas friendship to Paridel's seat</br>My muse in soft transport convey'd;</br>In friendship he hasten'd to meet,</br>And shorten my steps as I stray'd.

At life's earliest spring we began</br>By trifles our friendship to shew,</br>And as we matur'd into man,</br>Substantial and firmer it grew;</br>When absent he liv'd in my breast,</br>Unrival'd his joys were my own,</br>'Till love, profess'd rebel to rest,</br>Our intercourse view'd with a frown.

His thoughts were close link'd in my heart,</br>Their rivets affection had tied;</br>'Twas not in the slanderers art</br>Our mutual good-will to divide;</br>But cupid had Paridel found,</br>As well as his comfortless friend,</br>Reciprocal deepen'd the wound,</br>The other could each reprehend.

With day-spring whenever he rose,</br>Thy vales cultivation he sought;</br>The sun when unclouded it glows</br>Was not more refin'd than his thought;</br>His sentiment learning might teach,</br>Beam'd wisdom in Paridel's mien;</br>But beauty the wisest can teach,</br>Can brighten or sadden each scene.

Where plashes yon' murmuring fall,</br>As pensive meandring he stole</br>In silence to list to the call</br>Of whispers that waken the soul:</br>Here coolly oft eager to fly,</br>He woo'd the retirement of ease;</br>The muse with a fugitive eye,</br>Attended her master to please.

The pencil instructed to blend</br>The sylvan with subjects sublime,</br>To point the soft lays of a friend,</br>To love at once offer'd the rhime.</br>He sung of fair mildness and grace,</br>Of elegance sweetly refin'd:</br>The look that beams forth from the face,</br>From virtue irradiates the mind.

'Twas Clara he'd seen in his walk,</br>She stray'd by the lapse of the stream,</br>To Clara he ventur'd to talk,</br>Her beautiful form was his theme.</br>Of matchless allurements the maid</br>His tribute of passion receiv'd,</br>Believ'd what his sentiment said,</br>What his tenderness utter'd believed.

The mines of Potosi were poor</br>Compar'd to the wealth of his breast,</br>Felicity long to insure,</br>And lap his fond heart into rest;</br>The village was rouz'd with the morn,</br>God Hymen united the pair,</br>And thro' the brown vallies of corn,</br>Forgot was each sorrow and care.

In beauty's bright garden no flow'r</br>More brilliant than Clara was seen,</br>Had Venus display'd all her power,</br>Her charms would have rivall'd the queen</br>Of manners untinctured by pride,</br>With softness that won on the heart,</br>The sweetness of Paridel's bride,</br>Could all the engaging impart.

Happy shepherd, love's pinion of joy,</br>Your wishes has form'd into birth,</br>Be yours her bright smiles to employ,</br>With patronage honour her worth:</br>The lilies that whiten her neck,</br>To you in soft fragrance are given;</br>The roses that vermile her cheek,</br>Were gifts pre-ordain'd you by heav'n.

Her mind glows with elegant thought,</br>Supported by modesty's sense,</br>With all the serenity fraught</br>Which feelings unclouded dispense.</br>'Twas nature and love that combin'd</br>This union of bosoms to plan,</br>For happiness lasting design'd;</br>Live, Paridel!  thrice happy man!

You knew me, dear friend of my youth,</br>When pastime expanded her sail,</br>When friendship was measur'd by truth,</br>And health honied every gale.</br>Shall fancy look back on the scene,</br>When revell'd our hearts o'er the plain,</br>Revert to the sports of the green,</br>And call up puerility's reign.

When trifles as light as the air</br>Were objects of deepest concern;</br>'Twas mine my friend's lesson to share,</br>A monarch unpunish'd to learn;</br>And shall we on Russell bestow,</br>As well as his sceptre of birch,</br>What we from pure gratitude owe,</br>His precepts at school and at church.

Well pleas'd I remember the day,</br>When free from confinement and smart,</br>Our hearts were as jocund as May,</br>From learning and birch to depart.</br>Recall the warm transports we found,</br>December amid all thy gloom,</br>When Christmas with holidays crown'd,</br>Return'd us in jollity home.

But O these sensations of joy,</br>Unknown to disturbance and guile,</br>No longer our bosoms employ,</br>No longer compose with their smile.</br>Shall manhood than childhood less please,</br>Blest state, little shaded with care,</br>Maturity, stranger to ease,</br>Thy letters must Corydon wear.

The passions, a dangerous crew,</br>Embark on this ocean of strife,</br>Good sense and with competence few,</br>Can palliate the troubles of life.</br>Oh Paridel!  blest without pain,</br>How jocund your Corydon spoke,</br>How jovial he brought up the train</br>To dance in the shade of the oak.

To captivate, Emma was there,</br>Her smiles the young archer display'd,</br>Her dimples and innocent air</br>Exalted to notice the maid.</br>In vain I caress'd to be heard,</br>To picture what strongly I felt,</br>In stanza to utter the word,</br>'Twas pride that forbade her to melt.

Ah no, let me wrong not the fair,</br>Resentment be banish'd my breast,</br>For soon she found cause to declare</br>How much her fond heart was distrest.</br>Young Edwin her vows had approv'd,</br>Fair honour induc'd her to speak,</br>How much he deserv'd to be lov'd,</br>Yet a tear I perceiv'd on her cheek.

'Twas the dew drop of pity and grief,</br>The that from sympathy stole,</br>Thro' clouds it convey'd me relief,</br>Gave ease to the pangs of my soul.</br>How gen'rous and candid my maid,</br>Thy bosom's compassionate stream,</br>Has furnish'd me, delicate aid,</br>The tear for a pastoral theme.</br>
